Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2012 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. These fellowships support a research and training plan at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines. The title of the research and training plan for this fellowship to Thomas Koberda is "Dynamics of mapping class group representations and applications to right-angled Artin groups." The host institution for the fellowship is Yale University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Yair Minsky.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In the course of this award, the PI carried out research which studied the relationship between right-angled Artin groups and mapping class groups of surfaces. Right-angled Artin groups play a central role in modern three-manifold topology and geometric group theory, especially in light of the work of Agol, Wise, and their collaborators. Mapping class groups are central objects in geometric group theory, as well as many other disciplines of mathematics, and are essential for understanding topology in low dimensions.

The PI's work over the three year period of the award resulted in 10 publications, all of which were published or are to appear in high quality mathematical research journals. The PI's work has also been disseminated through the arXiv, a free preprint server, and through the PI's professional webpage.

Among the highlights of the PI's work during the period of the award are a proof that all right-angled Artin groups embed inside of pure braid groups, a further development of the Masur-Minsky curve complex machinery for right-angled Artin groups, and a complete development of the theory of convex cocompact subgroups of right-angled Artin groups.

In the course of this award, the PI has also had the opportunity to develop his mentoring skills through advising of non-mathematicians. In particular, he undertook the role of mentor in a reading course for an undergraduate at Yale University, which resulted in an expository paper. Serving as a mentor aided in the PI's professional development, as well as in the further education of his mentee.
